entry.title: Server Ping Monitoring through SAP Solution Manager
entry.content:
Hello SAP,

We are planning to implement Server Ping Monitoring through SAP Solution Manager (SolMan) as part of our proactive infrastructure health checks and availability monitoring strategy.

Objective:

The primary goal is to enable real-time monitoring of server availability by performing regular ICMP ping checks. This will help us detect unresponsive servers at an early stage, allowing for timely intervention and reduced service disruption.

Requirements:

  • Monitoring Scope: All critical application servers within the SAP landscape.
  • Check Frequency: Pings should be scheduled at regular intervals to continuously verify the availability of the target servers.
  • Alert Mechanism: In the event of a failed ping response, SolMan should trigger alerts via email and/or SMS to the relevant support teams as per the configured alert directory.

Request for Support:

We would appreciate your guidance on the following points:

  1. Is this functionality supported in SAP Solution Manager?
  2. Are there any predefined templates or configurations available for setting up server ping monitoring within SolMan?
  3. What are the recommended steps to proceed with implementation?

Your support and insights would be greatly appreciated as we move forward with this initiative.

Looking forward to your response


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Server Ping Monitoring through SAP Solution Manager
entry.content:
Hello team,

Thank you for reaching out with your inquiry about implementing Server Ping Monitoring with SAP Solution Manager. I'm pleased to provide guidance regarding the functionality and setup you're considering.

  1. Functionality in SAP Solution Manager: Server Ping Monitoring can be addressed using System Monitoring capabilities within SAP Solution Manager. This allows you to monitor the availability of your critical application servers and includes options for alerting when a server is unresponsive.

  2. Templates and Configurations: SAP Solution Manager provides predefined templates and configuration options for system monitoring. Specifically, System Monitoring and Advanced Monitoring features enable URL and ICMP ping checks to verify server availability.

  3. Implementation Steps: To proceed with setting up server ping monitoring, you’ll need to follow these general steps:

    • Configure the System Monitoring setup, including identifying target servers and defining the ping check parameters.
    • Set up alert mechanisms via the Alert Directory to ensure notifications are sent to the relevant support teams through email or SMS.

For further detailed information and guidance, please refer to the official documentation available on the SAP Help Portal. Here are some useful links:

  • SAP Solution Manager - System Monitoring Overview
  • SAP Solution Manager - Advanced Monitoring
  • Main concept of monitoring tools Learning

You can test running SOLMAN_SETUP / Application operations / System Monitoring  where you select the template and will enable not only availability monitoring, but also other metric categories as performance, configuration and exception.

For further prerequisite insights, review 2512142 - Monitoring and alerting: prerequisites to run System Monitoring correctly 

Best regards,
Luis Salazar

entry.title: Streamline invoice dispute with generative AI invoice error classification
entry.content:
The business impact of invoice rejection

Let’s face it, getting your invoice rejected is a pain. Not only because you need to find out what went wrong, but also because it means starting the process all over again, further delaying payment. And you’re not the only one experiencing pain. Ardent Partners’ 2024 trends shows that the invoice exception rate is consistently pretty high across most industries with a quarter of all invoices (25.5%) flagged for an exception. On the bright side, firms that use procure-to-pay technologies fare much better, with an exception rate of around 10%. SAP Business Network confirms this trends and even pushes it further, with an 11% of invoice exception rate in 2023 now down to 7% in June 2025! 

But even with technology that helps streamlining buyer-seller collaboration, there are many reasons that can lead your invoice to be rejected: price discrepancies, tax miscalculations, quantity errors, reconciliation with PO, paperwork missing, formatting of invoice reference… So the fastest way to solve the issue is to clearly understand the reasons for rejection. The problem there is that invoice rejections from external invoice processing system comprises of multiple rejection reasons in a semi structured format. These rejections offer a mix of user entered input and system generated rejection reasons, leading to a great effort in deciphering where the mistake lies.

 

Intelligent invoice error categorization and summarization

SAP Business Network introduces a new feature offering suppliers the option to use a generative AI functionality to classify and categorize the comments from the buyer's systems and users, so it will be clearer to them why their invoice was rejected. Using this functionality, the suppliers on SAP Business Network can:
• summarize and categorize the invoice rejection reasons,
• view this classified output on the invoice details page.
The rejection messages are segregated into different categories using a Large Language Model. Suppliers can use this classified information to get precise information on rejection details (Line number, Part number, Description), rejection category (user rejected, system rejected), rejection level (Generic, Header, Line) and and the Invoice field associated with the rejection, which helps them to identify and avoid recurring issues.

Watch the video

To view the categorized message, follow these steps:
1. Log in to your SAP Business Network account as a supplier.
2. Open a rejected invoice, either from the homepage or from the invoice tab.
3. Select the Simplify errors with AI toggle in the header of the invoice.

Activate the feature

The functionality is disabled by default for all the users and admins. A supplier administrator must enable the generative AI functionality for invoice in SAP Business Network by following these simple steps:
1. Log in to your SAP Business Network account as a supplier.
2. Go to Account Settings > Settings > Generative AI .
3. Select Invoice and then click Apply.

Other features enhanced by generative AI are also available for the administrator to activate from the same screen. 

Curious about more features or looking for information on how to maximize the use of your supplier account? Make sure to visit our dedicated page SAP Business Network for Suppliers | SAP Community.

entry.title: Re: CDS View I_GLACCOUNTHIERARCHY is empty in SAP S/4HANA...
entry.content:
There is some chance that you don't have the necessary rights on the data. There is an Access Control called I_GLAccountHierarchy linked with this CDS view using authorization object F_UNI_HIER.

This kind of issue is quite common and sometimes hard to figure it out as no errors will show up in SU53 or similar functionality and the authorization happens implicitly. Keep in mind the access condition here using the data on column HRYID and a fixed condition on the other authorization object fields. 

HRYID, HRYTYPE = 'FSVN', ACTVT = '03'

(snapshot taken in S/4HANA 2023 on-prem)

entry.title: Time Valuation to Allocate a Default of 8 Hours to TOIL for Saturdays, Regardless of Hours Worked
entry.content:
As a Time Management consultant, we come across many client requirements on a daily basis. Some of the requirements can be solved using standard solutions, while some need custom solutions. Recently, I got a requirement from client in Spain that they want to get a default 8Hours of time to TOIL Account ,  where if an employee works on Saturday which is either less than 8hours or more than 8hours , Default 8hours should be sent to TOIL account so later that employees can use that hours to take a comp-off leave as per the Spain legal regulations

Scenario: When employees work on Saturdays (Which is a non-working day as per work schedule), a default of 8 hours should be credited to their comp-off account, also known as the TOIL account, regardless of the actual hours worked on that day.

Steps to Achieve the Scenario:

To Achieve this scenario, In total I have configured a total of 3 valuations which are described below:

Valuation 1: Generate a fixed 8 hours within the specified time type group

 

Let's Decode Valuation 1:

This valuation is configured to get a fixed 8Hours into a time type group which will help us to carry those hours into Saturday Comp-off account on the recorded day .

Valuation Type: Create Time Record (This valuation is used to fetch the time specified within start and end time fields.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Time Type Group Above: Default 8HRS serves as the above group, which is used to store the total hours of start and end time which means 8hours as per the mentioned timings. The category of the above group is taken as calculated time, which is used to store the total hours. (Refer to screenshot 2 above)

Valuation 2: Identifying the hours worked on Saturday (Either of any hour recorded on saturday)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Let's Decode Valuation 2:

This valuation is used to fetch hours worked on Saturday which is a non-working day in my case as per work schedule.

Valuation Type: Filter Input Groups (This valuation is used to filter input groups based on given time record criteria.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Input Group: The Recorded Working Time group, used as working time, is assigned with my attendance types through which employee records time in timesheet (Refer to screenshot 2 above).

Time Records Filter: The Working Hours Saturday group is mainly used to specify Saturdays as non-working days according to my work schedule. I have specifically mentioned Saturdays and non-working days for greater precision. (Refer to screenshot 3 above)

Time Type Group Below: The Working Hours on Saturday group is used as the below group in above case, as the hours fetched by the filter group will always fall in this group. The time category of the below group is used as calculated time, which is mainly used to store the filtered hours. (Refer to screenshot 4 above)

Valuation 3: Compare Saturday Working hours, If more than 0 then route to above group regardless of hours recorded , which redirects the hours to TOIL Account


 

 

Let's Decode Valuation 3:

This valuation is designed to assess any time worked on Saturday and, if applicable, redirect the default 8 hours to the TOIL account. If no time is worked on Saturday, then no hours will be allocated to TOIL.

Valuation Type: Compare threshold with comparison group to route input (This valuation is used to compare the comparison group with a threshold and redirect the hours to either the above or below group.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Input Group: The Default 8HRS group is the result group from first valuation mentioned above, which stores the default 8 hours. (Refer to Valuation 1)

Comparison Group: The Working Hours on Saturday group is taken from the second valuation above, which records hours worked on Saturdays. (Refer to Valuation 2)

Threshold Group: In this scenario, I want to send 8 hours to the TOIL account for anyone who works on Saturday, regardless of the actual hours worked. Therefore, I have set the threshold value to 0, meaning that if the hours exceed 0, the default input group will be sent to TOIL. (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Time Type Group Above: The Saturday Default 8HRS into TOIL Group is used to store the hours and directly transfer them to the TOIL account, which employees can use to take time off. (Refer to screenshot 2 above)

Let's test this in timesheet:

Before Recording Time on Saturday

As you can see, before recording, there are no hours recorded on Saturday, and therefore, no hours have been sent to TOIL account which is also called as comp-off account.

After Recording Time on Saturday

In the screenshot above, you can see that I have recorded 1 hour on Saturday; then the default of 8 hours is sent to TOIL. In the TOIL tab, you can observe that 8 hours is added, while the summary shows the actual hours worked on Saturday as 1 hour, along with the default 8 hours sent to TOIL.

Hence, the same scenario can be used for Sunday's, Non-Working Days and Holiday's too

Thank you for reading! 😎
I hope this Blog provided valuable insights into unique Time Valuation. Feel free to share your thoughts, questions, or experiences in the comments below. Stay tuned for more SAP content!

entry.title: Re: Block shipment for certain time
entry.content:
Not sure whether this requirement is a regular requirement or an one-time requirement. If your requirement is just to block the stock, one simple and straight forward approach would be to create a delivery and save it so that the delivery quantity cannot be used for any other sales order.

If you also want to block shipment creation for two weeks, what you can do is after backflush, move HU-managed stock to a non-ship storage location or blocked stock. Create a batch job or MIGO movement to transfer stock back to the shipping location after 2 weeks. Advantage of going with this options are it physically prevents picking and shipment and works well with HU-managed locations. But on the other side, it requires additional stock movement logic and may need custom automation or manual intervention.

entry.title: Using List of Values in Document AI to classify documents and other validation tasks
entry.content:
Document AI (also known as Document Information Extraction previously) helps you to process large number of business documents of various layouts.

With the advancement of Generative AI and LLM, Document AI can now process various document types and more complex documents. Thanks to the support for list of values data type, it's more versatile than you might expect.

Let’s take a quick tour of what’s possible — and maybe spark some ideas for your next project.

Prerequisites:

  • Subscription to Document AI (Premium Edition)

 

Document Classification

Let’s say you’ve got a stack of documents — invoices, contracts, shipping receipts, and tax forms. Normally, sorting them would take hours.

With Document AI and natural language prompting, you can now say:

“Classify this document as one of: [‘CertificateOfCompliance’, ‘DeliveryOrder’, ServiceReport']”

The clearer the prompts, the better the results.

The following shows an example of a schema that used list of values to classify documents.

 

 

 

 

 

 

You can add a total of 20 values here for this data type.

 

Extension

I applied Document AI’s list of values feature to detect the presence of signatures within documents. While signature detection wasn’t the primary objective, leveraging this approach helps automate a key part of document validation.

The example below uses list of values to determine if there’s a signature.

 

To bring everything together, I created a custom schema that performs two key tasks: detecting the presence of a signature and classifying the document type. For this demonstration, I used a sample Certificate of Compliance. The model successfully identified that a signature was present and classified the document as a Certificate of Compliance. The output below illustrates the results.

 

Now Supports More Languages!

A major upgrade to Document AI is its expanding multilingual support. Now, you can extract, classify, and analyze documents written not just in English, but also in languages like Malay, Spanish, French, Japanese, and more.

 

In this post, I introduced how to leverage Document AI’s list of values feature to enhance your projects. . While signature detection wasn’t the primary objective, this use case highlights the flexibility and potential of combining structured schemas with prompting. There’s plenty of room to expand on this approach for more advanced document processing tasks.

 

See also:

  • Tutorials:
    • Setup BTP Trial Account
    • Setup Document AI in BTP Trial Account
  • List of values data type
  • Supported Languages

entry.title: Re: how create validation for OSPP table -HANA DB

At first glance, I think the problem is value of primary key. You should have CardCode ItemCode with space, not ItemCode CardCode without space. So try putting

("CardCode" || ' ' || "ItemCode")

instead of ("ItemCode"||"CardCode")

Usually in such situations when I am not sure how to set up parameters in stored procedure, I use this code that blocks every transaction and gives me exact parameter values:

begin
               error := 1;
               error_message := N'Block object ' || object_type || ', transaction ' || transaction_type
               	|| ', key ' || list_of_cols_val_tab_del || ', key num ' || num_of_cols_in_key || ', key list ' || list_of_key_cols_tab_del;
               end;

entry.title: Make fields mandatory/non-skippable for some login users in a Custom MDF Portlet
entry.content:
There can be a Client Requirement of making some fields mandatory/non-skippable in a Custom MDF Portlet for certain login users.

A similar Business Scenario is given below for better understanding

Business Scenario

A Client has a Custom Resignation Portlet(Custom MDF Portlet) configured in the People Profile in its SF instance. Client wants when the Manager edits any field value/inserts a record into the Custom Resignation Portlet in the People Profile certain important fields which should be filled up by only the Manager be made mandatory only for them. 

Limitations of MDF Objects

Unfortunately, we can't use the model version along with Business Rules here as it is applicable for HR Objects, but not for MDF Objects.

 

Current workaround:

Error Messages can be used to make the desired fields mandatory/non-skippable.

 The steps are given below as the above business scenario.

  1. Create an Error Message using Message Definition in Manage Data. A screenshot of the Message configured is given below.
  2. Configure a Business Rule with scenario as Rules for MDF Based Objects and purpose as Evaluate. A screenshot of the Business Rule is given below for the login user as Manager.

   3. Attach the Business Rule in the Save Rules section of the Object Configuration( Configure Object Definitions).

Final Result

When the Manager tries to skip the necessary fields an Error Message is been displayed and the record will not get saved until the fields are filled up.

Conclusion/Summary

Thanks for taking the time to read my blog. I hope the workaround illustrated in my blog  will help you to overcome the limitation of the MDF Object which earlier restricted us from making fields mandatory/non-skippable by Business Rules. 

Please feel free to give your honest feedback and ask any queries in the comment section of this blog. Also please share this blog with your colleagues.

entry.title: Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (1/2)
entry.content:
This blog is part of the series:

  1. Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (1/2)
  2. Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (2/2) 

1. Introduction

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions.

In SAP BDC, the Business Data Fabric provides capabilities and tools for the generation of a semantically enriched trusted data foundation underlying Intelligent Applications. Specifically, the two components that close the context gap between data and Artificial Intelligence (AI) are:

  • AI Foundation is SAP’s AI operating system provides the means to build, extend, and run custom AI solutions and agents at scale. It includes the generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, which is a rich set of AI capabilities (40+ and counting frontier AI models, orchestration etc.), for productive purpose, running on SAP Business Technology Platform.
  • SAP Databricks combines advanced Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML), data science, and engineering capabilities, with semantically rich data from SAP applications, in a pro-code environment.

In this blog post we explain how AI Foundation capabilities can be readily consumed in SAP Databricks, unlocking further potential, to generate AI-enhanced custom derived data products, for instance.

We demonstrate this through the example of SAP AI Core Orchestration Service, which provides harmonized access to a wide range of frontier AI models, and offers various configurable modules, such as for data masking or content filtering, that are executed in combination with the generative task of an AI model.

At the end of this blog post, you will have seen how a configured orchestration service can be exposed as an MLflow model, for fully integrated downstream processing in SAP Databricks.

Why SAP AI Foundation + SAP Databricks?

While SAP Databricks already comes with AI features, the addition of SAP’s AI Foundation gives you the following advantages:

  • SAP-managed access to most leading foundation models in the industry (such as AWS Bedrock, Azure OpenAI, Google Vertex AI, and many more; SAP Note 3437766 specifies the availability of generative AI models) and SAP-trained tabular AI models in future as well.
  • Single-subscription consumption of these models, without the need for model-specific licensing and/or deployments.
  • Additional features such as the Prompt Registry and Grounding services to facilitate desired instructions to generative models with right business context.
  • Train, serve, and operate traditional machine learning models, with enterprise-grade quality and scalability.

Who should read this blog post?

  • Data scientists, who want to enrich quality and applicability of data, by adding more business context;
  • Application developers, who want to understand what AI value additions can be covered already on the level of data products.

How is this blog post organized?

This is a technical, hands-on blog post. It is divided into the following sections:

  • Example use case
  • Preconditions
  • Generation of textual explanations
  • Registering a model in SAP Databricks
  • Summary and outlook

2. Example Use Case

This blog post uses General Ledger Accounting data, specifically from the Entry View Journal Entry data product, to illustrate a powerful integration pattern. For a typical enterprise, managing cash flow and mitigating payment delays are critical for business performance.

This integration provides actionable insights into predictions for delay in pending payments. The key aspect of this integration is the generation of explanations for such predictions in natural language, enabling business users to understand why a predicted delay is large or small, and which journal entry properties are relevant for the prediction. This is where generative AI capabilities of SAP AI Foundation come into play.

The focus of the blog post is on how AI Foundation explains the predictions, no on how the predictions are derived by corresponding ML methods. Before we get into the topic, here is a brief refresher of used terminology.

Payment delay predictions are directly related to the NetDueDate and ClearingDate elements of the Entry View Journal Entry:

  • Journal entries with NetDueDate and a ClearingDate represent cleared payments from the past.
  • A ClearingDate beyond the NetDueDate indicates a payment delay.
  • Journal entries without a ClearingDate represent pending payments.
  • The ClearingDate can be predicted by a ML model that can be trained on cleared payments.  
  • For these predictions, the values of certain journal entry elements will play a significant role (for example, for a certain Customer payments may be systematically delayed).

The generated explanation of a payment delay prediction may then be used to provide a verbal answer to these questions”

  • What are the few most significant elements for a specific journal entry?
  • To what extent do they drive the delay prediction in a positive or negative direction?

3. Preconditions

This section outlines the necessary preconditions, including product setup, data source configuration, ML model training, and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) value generation for the scenario demonstrated in this blog post.

3.1     Setup

This guide assumes you have access to an SAP Databricks instance within SAP Business Data Cloud. This guide also requires access to SAP Business Technology Platform and a configured SAP AI Core service instance with a corresponding service key (see e.g. the documentation for the initial setup). 

 

The high-level architecture of the integration between SAP BDC and SAP AI Core consists of the following components:

  • Data products are accessible via Delta Tables in the Unity Catalog.
  • Derived tables can be generated via Databricks notebooks / scripts.
  • SAP AI Core features such as the deployment on models and the orchestration service can be accesses via the AI API.
  • Access to SAP AI Core is granted via a service key that (together with the Resource Group name) is stored in a Databricks Secret.

While SAP AI Core capabilities are exposed via a REST API (see the documentation on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub), this guide leverages the SAP Cloud SDK for AI (Python) to simplify consumption within Databricks notebooks. This SDK is available as package sap-ai-sdk-gen for free download from PyPI and is documented on the SAP Help Portal.

To securely store and access SAP AI Core credentials from within SAP Databricks, create a Databricks secret. First, create a secret scope named aicore_service_params in your Databricks workspace (refer to Databricks documentation on creating secret scopes). Then, store the following access parameters as case-sensitive key-value pairs within this scope, as they are defined in the documentation of the generative AI SDK:

  • AICORE_BASE_URL
  • AICORE_AUTH_URL
  • AICORE_CLIENT_ID
  • AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET
  • AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP

In the context of this blog post, we use the “default” resource group. This allows us to interact with the orchestration service of AI Core as it is autogenerated already together with the service instance and can be used directly without the need for additional setup.

Databricks secrets provide a secure way to store sensitive credentials, allowing you to access them within your code without exposing the actual values to users. We can create these parameters as environment variables via the following script:

# This script retrieves SAP AI Core access parameters from a Databricks Secret and sets them as environment variables.
from databricks.sdk import WorkspaceClient
import os
w = WorkspaceClient()
for key in ["AICORE_CLIENT_ID", "AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET", "AICORE_AUTH_URL", "AICORE_BASE_URL", "AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP"]:
    os.environ[key] = w.dbutils.secrets.get(scope = "aicore_service_params", key=key)

 

Setting these credentials as environment variables allows the SAP Cloud SDK for AI (Python) to seamlessly authenticate and interact with the SAP AI Core orchestration service within the Databricks runtime. The SAP Cloud SDK for AI (Python) automatically manages the configuration and deployment of orchestration service endpoints and the desired Large Language Models (LLMs) upon initial use. You can view these deployments within the SAP AI Launchpad, the SAP BTP application for AI lifecycle management.

 

 

3.2 Data source

Our prediction scenario uses the Entry View Journal Entry data product from SAP S/4HANA Private Edition. An Entry View Accounting Document Item represents an individual transaction posted to an account within the accounting sub-ledger. The data used in this blog post is sourced from an internal test system. As a result, it is synthetic and may not fully reflect real-world customer scenarios. We used in total 8421 rows.

Each row represents a single accounting document item, identified by the following key columns: CompanyCode, AccountingDocument, FiscalYear, and AccountingDocumentItem.

Refer to this help page section for instructions on activating and sharing the data product from SAP Business Data Cloud to SAP Databricks.

3.3 Data Preparation

In this chapter we briefly outline the use case of the delay prediction based on the data product together with the SHAP value generation we later use for the model explanation.

For data preparation, we first drop all Date columns (with the exception of ClearingDate and NetDueDate) from the overall Spark dataframe and also exclude all columns which contain only null values from our data product. We further restrict our dataset to only those invoices which are related to a given customer. For all columns that have a string data type, we add a constant value marking it as a missing data entry for this specific column. After the cleansing of our dataset, we create our target variable which is used for our regression model.

In below’s code we calculate the delay of our invoices as the difference between NetDueDate and ClearingDate.

delay_prediction_dataset = (prepared_transactional_data.
    withColumn("delay", datediff("ClearingDate", "NetDueDate")))

 

Once the data preparation is finished, we store the results of our Delta Table in Unity Catalog in Databricks.

mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")
fe_client = FeatureEngineeringClient()
fe_client.create_table(
    name="prepared_accounting_document",
    primary_keys=primary_key,
    schema=delay_prediction_dataset.schema,
    description="Prepared Accounting document item data product for payment delay forecasting"
)
fe_client.write_table(
    name="prepared_accounting_document",
    df=delay_prediction_dataset,
    mode="merge"
)

 

3.4 ML model training and SHAP value generation

Using the prepared dataset, we perform hyperparameter tuning of an XGBoost regressor using the Optuna TPESampler. For our hyperparameter set we use the following parameters:

params = {
        "booster": "gbtree",
        "objective": "reg:squarederror",
        "tree_method": "hist",
        "max_depth": trial.suggest_int("max_depth", 3, 10),
        "learning_rate": trial.suggest_float("learning_rate", 1e-2, 3e-1, log=True),
        "n_estimators": trial.suggest_int("n_estimators", 200, 1500),
        "subsample": trial.suggest_float("subsample", 0.5, 1.0),
        "colsample_bytree": trial.suggest_float("colsample_bytree", 0.5, 1.0),
        "gamma": trial.suggest_float("gamma", 0.0, 5.0),
        "min_child_weight": trial.suggest_float("min_child_weight", 1.0, 10.0),
        "reg_alpha": trial.suggest_float("reg_alpha", 0.0, 1.0),
        "reg_lambda": trial.suggest_float("reg_lambda", 0.0, 1.0),
        "random_state": 42,
    }

 We ran our model training across 50 trials and selected the model with the lowest Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) for registration. The final refitted model is stored in Unity Catalog and is tagged as 'prod'.

import mlflow
registered_model = mlflow.register_model(f"runs:/{run.info.run_id}/model", "delay_prediction")
mlflow_client = mlflow.MlflowClient()
mlflow_client.set_registered_model_alias(name=registered_model.name, alias="prod", version=registered_model.version)

We then perform inference using the registered model to generate delay predictions on our prepared data. To understand the factors influencing each delay prediction, we generated SHAP values using the SHAP TreeExplainer. SHAP values quantify the contribution of each feature to the model's prediction for a specific row, providing insights into model behavior and enabling explainability. We used the TreeExplainer method since this works well with Tree-based models like XGBoost.

The generated SHAP values were then structured into a table with the following schema: 

- CompanyCode (PK): string
- AccountingDocument (PK): string
- FiscalYear (PK): string
- AccountingDocumentItem (PK): string
- NetDueDate: date
- delay_prediction: double
- shap_array: array
  - items
    - column_name: string
    - column_description: string
    - column_value: string
    - shap_value: double

The column description is derived from the comments which are part of the inference table in Databricks. See the image below for an example of the dataset structure. 

 

 

In the next blog post of this series, we will learn how SAP AI Core can be used to verbalize the SHAP values, enriching model explanations for business users within SAP BDC: Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (2/2) .

entry.title: Re: Is there any scope item related to VMI in S/4HANA Pub...
entry.content:
Hi @Kazuhiro_F 

The SAP Public Cloud Edition confirms there is no built-in scope item for Vendor‑Managed Inventory (VMI).

While SAP does support supplier-managed replenishment through the SAP Business Network for Supply Chain, this functionality is not delivered as part of the standard S/4 Public Cloud scope items. It works through an external integrated scenario and you can find details here: Replenishment: Forecasts

If you need true VMI functionality, you'd be working outside the out-of-the-box scope and would need to explore integration with the Business Network for Supply Chain where your supplier manages replenishment remotely using shared inventory data Supplier-Managed Inventory | SAP Help Portal . Or you might consider other deployment options.

Best regards,

Chris

entry.title: Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (2/2)
entry.content:
This blog is part of the series:

  1. Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (1/2)
  2. Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (2/2) 

In the previous blog of this series - Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (1/2)- we have used the Journal Entry data product to predict the payment delays utilizing SAP Databricks ML capabilities. As a result, we trained an ML Model and generated the corresponding SHAP values (SHapley Additive exPlanations ).

In the following blog post we will use SAP AI Core to verbalize these SHAP values, and provide a model explanations for business users.

 

4. Generation of Textual Explanations

While SHAP values offer a powerful explanation of the prediction for data scientists, they can be difficult to interpret directly for business users. Therefore, we leverage a generative AI model to translate these SHAP values into a clear, textual explanation tailored for business users. The resulting model explanation can then be exposed to SAP Business Data Cloud as part of a derived data product.

The overall process of sharing data products between SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Databricks is described in the recent blog post SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud : Unifying SAP Business Data with Lakehouse Intelligence. By performing this natural language generation within Databricks, we leverage the scalable compute and data processing capabilities of the lakehouse to efficiently generate explanations for a large volume of predictions.

A verbal explanation of a delay_prediction from a shap_array can be generated using a Large Language Model (LLM) with a suitable prompt.

Instead of directly consuming a LLM for that purpose, we use the orchestration service of the Generative AI Hub because it offers a variety of features such as

  • the Prompt Registry for the management prompt templates,
  • the capability to mask personal or enterprise critical information,

and various other features, although the exploitation of these additional features is beyond the scope of this article.  

In this blog we aim at an integration that allows us to seamlessly track and manage LLM-powered explanation generation within the existing MLflow model lifecycle. With the Langchain integration of SAP GenAI hub for a direct integration into the MLflow ecosystem exists. This allows users to directly interact with the Databricks ecosystem and provides a possibility to cover the different aspects. Details of the langchain autolog functionality can be found here.

In the following we demonstrate how the additional capabilities of the orchestration service can be leveraged in combination with MLflow in Databricks to generate our model explanations for the delay prediction. We use the orchestration service of GenAI Hub via the SAP Cloud SDK for AI (Python) as documented here.

The orchestration service can be initialized by the provided SDK functions and allows the definition of different modules. In our example, we use a GPT-4o-mini model with a maximum token limit of 1000. In our example, we directly use Prompt Template of AI Core without the prompt registry functionality.

For the integration into MLflow, we provide a custom Python class derived from mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel. The Python class is elaborated in the following with the methods

  • __init__(…) to instatiate the class
  • load_context(…) to instantiate the orchestration service
  • predict(…) to generate the verbal explanations

 

4.1 The __init__(…) class method

For the init function we define in total three different parameters. The llm_model variable which stores the model name, the max_tokens parameter as well as the orchestration_service, which will store the orchestration service instance. As the instance references an external connection, we populate the variable in the load_context method.

In the following, the overall implementation can be found.

class ExplanationModel(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
    def __init__(self):
        self.llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini"
        self.max_tokens = 1000
        self.orchestration_service = None

 

4.2 The load_context(…) class method

As outlined above, the load_context method is used to establish the connection to an external service from the MLflow custom class. A detailed explanation of the setup of the mlflow pyfunc PythonModel class can be found under the following tutorial article.

In our load_context method we provide a prompt template, which differentiates between the system message and the user message. The system message consists of a general explanation what the task for the LLM is and describes the static schema of the input parameter. Within the user message, the row specific details are populated over separate variables. For the first variable shap_array the SHAP explanations are stored in an array consisting for each variable of a respective JSON structure. The second variable delay_prediction provides the predicted payment delay as a context for the LLM.

After the definition of the template values, the orchestration_service  variable gets overwritten by the instantiation of the OrchestrationService class. The class generally provides an overall OrchestrationConfiguration, which we fill on our side with the prompt template as well as the LLM instance.

def load_context(self, context={}) -> None:
        """
        Loads the context required for the orchestration model by setting environment variables from Databricks secrets and initializing the orchestration service with the specified configuration.

        The configuration includes the template for user messages and the LLM model parameters.

        This method does not take any parameters and does not return any values.
        """
        template = Template(
            messages=[
                SystemMessage('You are a data scientist who explains predictions of a business artificial intelligence model.\nThe model predicts the expected delay for a payment.\nYour task is to explain this specific prediction in a concise manner to a business person who is not a data scientist and who wants to understand which features are relevant for the prediction.Do not mention the SHAP values in your explanation. You can use the feature vales. The SHAP values with the top 5 SHAP values are stored in a JSON array and is structured in the following: [{"column_name": column name, "shap_value": Non normalized SHAP values for column, "column_description": Column description, "column_value": Value of the column}]'),
                UserMessage(
                    'The row has the following SHAP value:{{ ?shap_array }}The row with the SHAP value has the following delay prediction of the payment:{{ ?delay_prediction }}A negative SHAP value for a feature means that the feature value reduces the prediction below average, while a positive value means that the feature value increases the prediction above average.'
                ),
            ]
        )
        orchestration_config = OrchestrationConfig(
            template=template,
            llm=LLM(name=self.llm_model, parameters={"max_tokens": self.max_tokens})
        )

        self.orchestration_service = OrchestrationService(config = orchestration_config)

 

4.3 The predict(…) class method

For the predict method, we expect in total two different variables: The model_input variable which receives the model input as well as the params variable, which by default has the value “none”. Generally, a user could overwrite the aspects in this regard, but in our blog post example we do not leverage the parameter variable which is required to be provided in the predict method.

For the overall output generation, we iterate over each individual role of the pandas dataframe. In the very first step, we extract the primary keys to return them in combination with the generated delay_explanation. The variables shap_array as well as the delay_prediction are used to fill the prompt template we used for the orchestration configuration. As outlined in the beginning of the blog post, we focus on the five variables with the highest abolute SHAP values, which we filter out using the following script line: 

 filtered_shap_values = sorted(shap_values, key = lambda x: (abs(x["shap_value"])), reverse=True)[:5]

Once we have prepared the input of our data, we start our MLflow span to log our traces for the individual completion task. We name the span shap_explanation and use the span type of LLM. Within the MLflow span, we populate our orchestration model with the respective parameters and provide those as an input referencing the service instance  self.orchestration_service. When capturing the output, we store the orchestration result in the variable orchestration_result. To allow the logging of the system and user messages within mlflow, we extract those from the orchestration service for the individual run.

with mlflow.start_span(name="shap_explanation", span_type="LLM") as span:
                try:
                    orchestrationResponse = self.orchestration_service.run(template_values=template_values)
                    orchestration_result = orchestrationResponse.orchestration_result

                    completion = orchestration_result.choices[0].message.content
                    messages = [{"role": message.role.value, "content": message.content} for message in orchestrationResponse.module_results.templating]

This above information is provided to the started mlflow span and populated accordingly.

set_span_chat_messages(span, messages)
                    row_result["deplay_explanation"] = completion
                    span.set_attributes({"model_name": self.llm_model, "max_tokens": self.max_tokens})
                    span.set_inputs({"shap_values": str(filtered_shap_values), "delay_prediction": str(row["delay_prediction"])})

 In case during the inference time an error occurs, this is specifically logged as an event together with the entire stack trace. This allows to investigate what exactly might have gone wrong from the overall inference run. After everything went through, we append the orchestration output to the list and return it later back as a Pandas dataframe.

except OrchestrationError as error:
                    model_output.append(error.message)
                    span.add_event(SpanEvent.from_exception(error))

model_output.append(row_result)

The complete code for the predict method can be found under the following code snippet.

def predict(self, model_input, params=None):
        """ We expect a Pandas DataFrame as input"""

        model_output = []
        rows = model_input.to_dict(orient='records')
        for row in rows:
            row_result = {}
            primary_keys = ["CompanyCode", "AccountingDocument", "FiscalYear", "AccountingDocumentItem"]
            for key in primary_keys:
                row_result[key] = row[key]
            shap_values = row["shap_array"]
            filtered_shap_values = sorted(shap_values, key = lambda x: (abs(x["shap_value"])), reverse=True)[:5]
            template_values = []
            template_values.extend([TemplateValue(name="shap_array", value=str(filtered_shap_values)), TemplateValue(name="delay_prediction", value=str(row["delay_prediction"]))])
            with mlflow.start_span(name="shap_explanation", span_type="LLM") as span:
                try:
                    orchestrationResponse = self.orchestration_service.run(template_values=template_values)
                    orchestration_result = orchestrationResponse.orchestration_result

                    completion = orchestration_result.choices[0].message.content
                    messages = [{"role": message.role.value, "content": message.content} for message in orchestrationResponse.module_results.templating]
                    messages.append({"role": "assistant", "content": completion})
                    set_span_chat_messages(span, messages)
                    row_result["deplay_explanation"] = completion
                    span.set_attributes({"model_name": self.llm_model, "max_tokens": self.max_tokens})
                    span.set_inputs({"shap_values": str(filtered_shap_values), "delay_prediction": str(row["delay_prediction"])})
                    span.set_outputs({"delay_explanation": completion})

                except OrchestrationError as error:
                    model_output.append(error.message)
                    span.add_event(SpanEvent.from_exception(error))

                model_output.append(row_result)

        pd_model_output = pd.DataFrame.from_records(model_output)
        return pd_model_output

Since the code snippet already gets a bit lengthy, we refrain from a few aspects that should be considered to optimize the throughput in productive usage:

  • The processing time of an individual row by a LLM typically lies in the range of seconds. To accelerate the processing of larger data frames, one can use Python’s concurrent features to replace the sequential for loop over rows.  
  • Calls to language models are imposed with rate limits, for instance the number of requests per minute that can be processed for a specific model in a tenant (see SAP Note 3437766). Given concurrent requests LLM requests, individual requests can run into “429 – too many requests” exceptions. These can be handled for example by retrying failed requests with exponential backoff (see e.g. OpenAI Cookbook “How to handle rate limits”) .

As these are “standard” practices to increase processing throughput and to handle rate limits that are independent of the integration aspect we focus on, we do not go into the related coding details.

 

5. Orchestration service as a logged MLflow model

 With the above definition of the custom MLflow class in a Python file, we proceed to log and register our model within the (SAP) Databricks Unity catalog. For this, by using the following code, we can register the model within the Unity catalog of (SAP) Databricks.

 The AICORE_... access parameters mentioned in the setup need to be available as environment variables

from databricks.sdk import WorkspaceClient
import os
w = WorkspaceClient()
for key in ["AICORE_CLIENT_ID", "AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET", "AICORE_AUTH_URL", "AICORE_BASE_URL", "AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP"]:
    os.environ[key] = w.dbutils.secrets.get(scope = "aicore_service_params", key=key)

when the custom MLflow model class is instantiated which happens implicitly when the model is logged:

mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")
registered_model = mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
    artifact_path="model",
    python_model="mlflow_llm_artifact.py",
    input_example=input_data,
    signature=model_signature,
    registered_model_name="shap_verbalizer_orchestration",
    pip_requirements=[
        "sap-ai-sdk-gen[all]"
    ])

Once the model is registered, it can be found within the Unity Catalog containing the different versions associated to the model. A model tag allows the possibility to always reference the newest model version within the Unity Catalog. Therefore, model version updates which have been triggered by the developer can be directly taken into account by referencing the overall mlflow tag.

Once we stored the model within the Unity Catalog, the developer has the possibility to use that logged model in multiple ways to allow the model configuration to be directly executed:

  • Load mlflow model and apply it over a Spark or Pandas dataframe
  • Create model serving endpoint to expose it over a static API and/ or apply the ai_query SQL syntax to apply it over a Spark dataframe of a served entity

5.1 MLflow based inference

In order to apply our logged model to a dataframe, we can inference our data based on a Pandas dataframe as well as a Spark dataframe.

For the inference of the deployed model over Databricks, we can directly load the mlflow logged mlflow model. To authenticate the AI Core instance for our inference, we directly provide the respective AI Core credentials. After this step, we are able to load our model, read the dataset in as a Pandas dataframe and then apply our dataset on the logged model. In the following, the inference script for the GenAI enhancement is outlined:

from databricks.sdk import WorkspaceClient
import os
w = WorkspaceClient()
for key in ["AICORE_CLIENT_ID", "AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET", "AICORE_AUTH_URL", "AICORE_BASE_URL", "AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP"]:
    os.environ[key] = w.dbutils.secrets.get(scope = "aicore_service_params", key=key)
loaded_model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model("models:/shap_verbalizer_orchestration@prod")
input_data = spark.read.table("delay_prediction_dataset_shap").drop("NetDueDate").toPandas()
with mlflow.start_run() as run:
    model_output = loaded_model.predict(input_data)

fe = FeatureEngineeringClient()
fe.create_table(df=spark_model_output, name="shap_verbalization", primary_keys=["CompanyCode", "AccountingDocument", "FiscalYear", "AccountingDocumentItem"], schema=spark_model_output.schema)
fe.write_table(df=spark_model_output, name="shap_verbalization")

In case as an end user we want to directly apply our models to a Spark dataframe, we need to leverage a classic compute instance. Currently, for the serverless workload Databricks does not provide the possibility to expose credentials to each individual spark executor. In order to apply the execution of the stored orchestration model over a Spark dataframe, we need to add our secrets to the cluster configuration as outlined in the following Databricks help documentation. In the following we have added the Spark config we used for our cluster:

spark.executorEnv.AICORE_AUTH_URL {{secrets/aicore_service_params/AICORE_AUTH_URL}}
spark.executorEnv.AICORE_BASE_URL {{secrets/aicore_service_params/AICORE_BASE_URL}}
spark.executorEnv.AICORE_CLIENT_ID {{secrets/aicore_service_params/AICORE_CLIENT_ID}}
spark.executorEnv.AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET {{secrets/aicore_service_params/AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET}}
spark.executorEnv.AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP {{secrets/aicore_service_params/AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP}}

All details how the model can be loaded from mlflow and be executed on a spark dataframe as a spark_udf function are outlined here:

spark_model =  mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf(spark, "models:/<<CATALOG>>.<<SCHEMA>>.shap_verbalizer_orchestration@prod")
from pyspark.sql.functions import struct, col
input_data = spark.read.table("delay_prediction_dataset_shap").limit(200).drop("NetDueDate")
spark_predict_df = input_data.withColumn("prediction", spark_model(struct(*map(col, input_data.columns))))
display(spark_predict_df)
fe = FeatureEngineeringClient()
fe.create_table(df=spark_predict_df, name="shap_verbalization_spark", primary_keys=["CompanyCode", "AccountingDocument", "FiscalYear", "AccountingDocumentItem"], schema=spark_predict_df.schema)
fe.write_table(df=spark_predict_df, name="shap_verbalization_spark")

In the following we will provide an outline for the second inference possibility using the serving endpoint of Databricks itself.

5.2 Serving endpoint

Each registered model within the Databricks Unity Catalog can be used within a serving endpoint in Databricks. Generally, this serving endpoint allows to define different details around the characteristics of an API endpoint which allows us to tailor the overall endpoint for our needs. Once we reference our model within the catalog, we can deploy our model serving endpoint. This allows us to interact with a deployed model and directly bind it within a CAP application or any other web application directly leveraging the enrichment done and provided by an AI Core deployed orchestration model.

In addition, users can directly leverage the AI Query command within SAP Databricks (Public preview) and provide an endpoint for an end-to-end enrichment from a stored table within the Unity Catalog. In below code you can find the SQL script which references the served model and provides the output from the orchestration model as an additional column.

SELECT
CompanyCode,
AccountingDocument,
FiscalYear,
AccountingDocumentItem,
delay_prediction,
  ai_query(
    endpoint => 'shap_verbalization_endpoint',
    request => named_struct(
      'CompanyCode', CompanyCode,
      'AccountingDocument', AccountingDocument,
      'FiscalYear', FiscalYear,
      'AccountingDocumentItem',AccountingDocumentItem,
      'shap_array',shap_array,
      'delay_prediction',delay_prediction)
    ).delay_explanation AS model_explanation
FROM <<CATALOG>>.<<SCHEMA>>.delay_prediction_dataset_shap

5.3     Sharing our scored dataset back to BDC

As we have our dataset now provided with our delay prediction as well as our model explanation based on SHAP values, we want to share our results back as a Data Product to BDC. To do so, we leverage the stored dataset in our unity catalog and run for the exposure of our data product from SAP Databricks to the BDC catalog. In order to do so, we leverage the Delta Sharing capabilities together with the overall aspects of the metadata generation of our data product. A detailed guide for the sharing process can be found here: https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud/monitoring-and-extending-data-products-with-sap-business-data-cloud/c4464c041dec43b58a32501c6a6dda3a.html?locale=en-US

  • Based on our table we create a Delta Share, where we add the sap-business-data-cloud recipient. In our case, we name the share delay_prediction_share.
  • In addition, we go further in exposing the Delta Share to the Delta Catalog using the sap-bdc-connect-sdk package

 Below the used code for the sharing can be found:

from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import BdcConnectClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import DatabricksClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.utils import csn_generator
import json

with BdcConnectClient(DatabricksClient(dbutils)) as bdc_connect_client:
    share_name = "delay_prediction_share"

    try:
        share_body = {
            "type": "REMOTE_SHARE",
            "provider": {
                "type": "FEDERATION",
                "name": "databricks"
            },
            "@openResourceDiscoveryV1": {
                "title": "Payment delay prediction explanation",
                "shortDescription": "Payment delay prediction with explanations generated by a LLM",
                "description": "The table contains data related to accounting documents and their associated delays. It includes information such as the company code, fiscal year, and specific accounting document items. This data can be used to analyze delays in accounting processes, understand the reasons behind these delays, and improve overall efficiency in financial reporting."
            }
        }

        share_request_body = json.dumps(share_body)

        catalog_response = bdc_connect_client.create_or_update_share(
            share_name,
            share_request_body
        )
        csn_schema = csn_generator.generate_csn_template(share_name)
        csn_schema_string = json.dumps(csn_schema)

        csn_response = bdc_connect_client.create_or_update_share_csn(
            share_name,
            csn_schema_string
        )
        publish_response = bdc_connect_client.publish_data_product(
            share_name,
        )
    except Exception as ex:
        print(f"Exception when creating or updating share(name={share_name}): {ex}\n")

Once we share our dataset back from the Databricks instance to BDC, we can see our derived data product from which we can interact with from the BDC instance.

In the following chapter, we provide a summary as well as an outlook for the next steps.

 

6 Summary and Outlook

In this blog we have shown for the AI Core orchestration service how it can be used in SAP Databricks

  • as a MLflow model
  • with an endpoint service deployment, and
  • with comprehensive model tracing.

To achieve this, we just needed

  • an available AI Core service instance and 
  • to work with its access parameters (we chose to pack them into a Databricks secret).

Let’s recall that the orchestration service is just one example of the broad spectrum of capabilities provided by SAP AI Core as the central component of SAP AI Foundation. This spectrum furthermore includes

  • services that complement generative AI, such as the Grounding service, the Prompt Registry service, and the new Prompt Optimizer for generative AI,
  • classical ML model training and serving,
  • and soon also tabular AI including foundation models trained on business data. (see e.g. the blog Leveraging Generative AI Advancements for Linked Business Data)

Capabilities of SAP AI Foundation [SAP Sapphire 2025 global keynote @1:00:44]   

While this article is describing an integration mechanism between SAP AI Foundation and SAP Business Data Cloud, it is planned to simplify and strengthen this integration such that the broader SAP AI Foundation capabilities can be consumed out of SAP Databricks in the smoothest possible way.

Planned enhancements include

  • automatic provisioning of AI Core service instances along with SAP Databricks instances with established trust to exempt the SAP Databricks user from handling service keys
  • batch processing for the AI Core orchestration service to simplify processing of tabular data
  • support for tracking of AI Core capabilities into external (e.g. SAP Databricks) tracking servers

In sequel blogs we plan to cover integration scenarios for SAP AI Foundation capabilities beyond the simple usage of the orchestration service.

This blog is part of the series:

      1. Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (1/2)
      2. Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (2/2)

entry.title: ONB 2.0: Assign Onboarding Data Collections dynamically using a Lookup Table
entry.content:
This article dives into a practical and scalable solution using a Lookup Table to automate data collection assignments based on criteria like legal entity, location, citizenship, and employment type. Whether you're an SAP admin or a functional consultant, this guide will walk you through the setup process step-by-step, helping you reduce manual configuration and enhance onboarding efficiency.

Pre-requisites:

  1. Appropriate Role-Based Permissions has been granted to the admin. The Permission should allow the admin to:
    • Create Data Collections
    • Access Object Definitions
    • Manage Data (Import / Export) for the MDF Objects
    • View and download from the Scheduled Job Manager
    • Update Business Rules

  2. The MDF Objects to be used in the Data Collection has been created.
  3. The ConfigUI for the MDF objects has been setup and designed already.
  4. Custom Onboarding Data Collections has been created already.
  5. ConfigUI has been associated to the different Onboarding Data Collections

Step 1: Create the Lookup Table which will be used to assign the Data Collections

Create an MDF Object Lookup Table which has all the conditions that will determine which Data Collection will be assigned to the new hire.

  1. Go to Admin Center → Configure Object Definitions

  2. On the right-hand side, click on the Create New dropdown then select Object Definition

  3. Define the Object:

    Code:ONB_ADC_LookupTable
    Effective Dating: None
    API VisibilityNot Visible
    StatusActive
    MDF Version HistoryNo Selection
    LabelONB Data Collection Lookup Table

  4. Set the fields. The Fields you create will depend on the employee or job information attributes that you need to assess when assigning a data collection. 
    Note: Generic Objects can be used in the Lookup Table.

    The String and Generic objects data type was added for comparison in this lookup table object being created. You may choose to retain only the Generic Object fields in your lookup object.

    NameData TypeLabelValid Values Source
    externalcodeString  
    externalNameString  
    cust_countryStringCountry 
    cust_countryObjGeneric ObjectCountry ObjectCountry
    cust_legalentityStringLegal Entity 
    cust_LEobjGeneric ObjectLegal Entity ObjectLegalEntity
    cust_locationStringLocation 
    cust_empclassStringEmployee Class 
    cust_datacollectionGeneric ObjectData CollectionONB2DataCollectionConfig




  5. Set the Security. Under the Security section, set Secured to Yes
  6. Define Permissions Category Onboarding or Offboarding Object Permissions
  7. Save the Object



  8. Permission the newly created object to the Admin user.

Step 2: Update the Lookup Table

It is possible to update the lookup table directly via Manage Data  or via Import and Export Data. 

To update via Manage Data, follow the steps below:

  1. Go to Manage Data
  2. Click on Create New > ONB Data Collection Lookup Table


  3. Update the Fields. 
    Use the External Code for the String Fields such as the Country, Legal Entity, Location,  Employee Class
    The Generic Objects data type will allow you to select the data maintained already for the objects like the Country, Legal Entity or Onboarding Data Collection. 



  4. Assign the appropriate Data Collection for the different combinations of the Country, Legal Entity, Location, Employee Class, etc. 

To update via Import and Export Data, follow the steps below:

  1. Go to Import and Export Data
  2. Export Data > ONB Data Collection Lookup Table
  3. Click on Export then click on View Result.
  4. In the Scheduled Job Manager page, download the zip file for the ONB Data Collection Lookup Table.
     
  5. Extract the contents of the zip file and open the ONB Data Collection Lookup Table file. 

    Note the difference on the column headers for the String versus the Generic Objects data type. 
  6. Update the file and add the different conditions that will be used to assign the Onboarding Data Collection. Save the changes and set the file type to  CSV UTF-8 (Comma Delimited)
  7. Go back to Import and Export Data. 
  8. Select Import Data
  9. Upload the file. Select UTF-8 for the encoding. 
  10. Click Validate and if there are no errors then Import the file. 

Step 3: Update the ConfigSelect Rule

  1. Go to Configure Business Rules.
  2. Search for the ONB2_DataCollectionConfigSelect rule
  3. Open and Actions > Make Corrections to the rule. 
  4. Set the ConfigSelect conditions as shown below.
    Note how the Data Collection is not defined in the rule but is assigned based on the Data Collection inside the ONB Data Collection Lookup Table. 

With the use of the lookup table, you only have one block defined for Germany. However, inside the lookup table, you could have different combinations defined that will determine which Onboarding Data Collection will be assigned to the new hire. 

To Check if the correct Data Collection was assigned, Add a new hire to Onboarding with a position that meets all the attributes in the Onboarding Data Collection Lookup Table.

For this example, we created a position that has the following attributes.

Country/Region.Country/Region Code (3 char)DEU
Legal Entity.Legal Entity IDACE_DEU
LocationGER_FRA
Employee ClassM

 After completing the Review New Hire Data and Provide Personal Data step, follow the steps below:

  1. Get the Person ID or the Employee ID
  2. Go to Manage Data > Process > Type the Person ID
  3. Look for the customDataCollectionConfig field 

If you have set everything up correctly, then the Data Collection you have assigned should be reflected correctly.

Conclusion:
By leveraging a Lookup Tables in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding 2.0, organizations can significantly simplify the management of data collections while ensuring accuracy and compliance. This approach not only reduces administrative overhead but also enhances the new hire experience by delivering relevant forms and data fields tailored to their profile. As demonstrated, setting up the table, updating it via Manage Data or Import tools, and integrating it with business rules creates a dynamic, responsive onboarding process. 

Please feel free to drop any comments or questions. Thanks! 

Note: All photos are taken from a Demo environment.

entry.title: Re: Tax base error during downpayment clearing in MIRO
entry.content:
When you clear a down payment during MIRO, SAP expects the tax base to be correctly calculated for the clearing line item. If the tax base is missing or zero, the system throws an error, Since the same clearing works fine in F-44 is because it does not validate tax base the same way.

Couple of areas you need to check are

  • fs00 where, the Tax Category is set to allow input tax (e.g., “+” or “V”).
  • In the MIRO screen, ensure a valid tax code is selected for the invoice. The tax code must be applicable to both the invoice and the down payment clearing line.
  • OBCL controls tax code determination for non-vendor lines. Make sure your down payment clearing account is included in OBCL for your company code.

Finally, try simulating the invoice in MIRO and go to Environment → Messages. This will show you exactly which line item is causing the tax base error and why.

entry.title: Guide to Setting up a Personal Combined Statement in SAP SuccessFactors Compensation
entry.content:
Introduction:

When the organization transforms their strategies for compensation & Variable Pay, SAP SuccessFactors guides the way to provide an innovative solution that improves the employee experience. I am creating this post to make you understand the compensation statement along with how to configure a personal combined statement.

What is a Compensation Statement:

           The Compensation Statement in our SuccessFactors helps you to understand the compensation package. The SuccessFactors creates us an individual document that provides employees complete compensation information. Usually the Compensation Statement details include:

  • Base Salary: The fixed amount/pay an employee gets on a regular basis.
  • Variable Pay: Performance-based bonuses or incentives.
  • Benefits: Health insurance, retirement plans, etc.
  • Equity/Stock Options: If applicable, details about stock grants or options.
  • Other Compensation components: Other compensation components are allowances, commissions, or bonuses etc.,

The purpose of the compensation statement is to make employee’s/Managers understand the full value of the compensation. It is also useful to understand not only the salary part but also the other rewards & benefits they receive. It is typically utilized in employee self-service portals; it can be customized to align with the organization’s specific compensation structure.


The Personal Combined Statement enables us to consolidate and display two or more compensation plans within a single statement.

How to Configure a Personal combined statement:

To Configure the Personal Combined Statement, follow the below steps:

Step 1: go to Compensation Home > Action for All Plans

Step 2: Compensation Home > Action for All Plans > Manage Statement Templates.

Step 3: Click on Add Template > Select from Success Store > Combined Template

Step 4: Select any option as per your/organization requirements - Select the Add to my Instance option.

Step 5: Name the Template > “Test Compensation Combined Statement 2025” > Save.

Step 6: Choose your Compensation/Variable Pay Plans for the Statement Template (Minimum of 2 Plans – Either Compensation/ Variable Pay) > Click on Done.

The statement has been successfully created with the selected Compensation/Variable Pay plans. We can now adjust or customize it to meet our organization requirements.

How to Add new Compensation / Variable Pay Fields/Section:

Click Add Field > Source – Plan > Select a plan: "Compensation Plan" > Select a field > "Choose the desired compensation plan fields".

In the 1H 2025 SAP release, you can now be able to add EC fields directly to the compensation statements.

To do that:

Click on Add Field > Source – Employee Central > Select the EC category: Compensation Information/Employment Details/Job Information > Choose the desired EC field. (It is an Automatically enabled feature in 1H 2025)

Add Section – To create a new section that separates the fields in the statement.

Edit / Delete the Fields/Section: Hover your cursor over a field or section, then click the pencil icon to edit the details.

What is Company Logo URL Section: Here you can change or resize your company logo by clicking the pencil icon.

What is Statement Message Section: In this section you can either Edit or update your statement message by clicking the pencil icon.

What is Compensation Statement Section: You can either Modify or update the details of your statement. If you want to add a new text section, click on “Add Text Section.”

What is Signature Section: To Edit or add a signature of your Organization's Manager/CEO, Managing Director, etc...,

Save – Save the compensation statement.

Save As – Use this to copy compensation statement and save it as a new one.

Preview – This option allows you to view the saved or edited statement.

Cancel – This option allows you to cancel all the unsaved changes in the statement.

Conclusion:

In Summary, SAP SuccessFactors Compensation Statements offer organizations a tool to enhance the compensation process. They promote clarity, transparency and alignment with companies’ objectives. These statements enable employees to better understand their overall rewards, thereby increasing engagement and improving retention.
