entry.title: Commitments in focus: How SAP S/4HANA is changing the management of financial commitments
entry.content:
What does commitment mean in the SAP context? 

Commitments describe the outstanding financial obligations of a company. These include, for example, orders, provisions or approved but not yet utilized funds. Although no payment has yet been made, these items impact liquidity, budgeting and risk assessment. 

SAP records such obligations in the system in several modules, in particular in Materials Management (MM), Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO). It is precisely at this interface that SAP S/4HANA’s decisive advantage emerges. 

GRAPHIC 1: Schematic overview of commitment processing between MM, FI and CO 

From static reporting to real-time insight 

SAP ECC already offered the option of managing commitments. However, the flow of information was often sluggish, fragmented and poorly integrated. Analyses were based on upstream reports that rarely reflected the current data situation. 

SAP S/4HANA solves this problem with real-time data processing. Every relevant transaction, be it an order, an investment application or a provision, is immediately recorded in the system and can be analyzed instantly. The underlying SAP HANA database ensures that data is not only quickly available but also intelligently linked. 

Comparison of COOI and ACDOCA: the evolution of commitment management 

A key difference between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in how financial obligations are managed and mapped. In SAP ECC, the COOI table (open orders, accruals and commitments) played a central role in commitment management. This table recorded open items and provided an overview of financial obligations but was often static and limited in terms of updates. 

With SAP S/4HANA, commitments are managed via the ACDOCA table. This central financial accounting table offers several advantages: 

  1. Real-time data processing:
    ACDOCA enables the recording and evaluation of transactions in real time. This means that every change is immediately reflected in the system, resulting in an up-to-date and accurate representation of financial obligations.      
  2. Integrated data structure:
    In contrast to the fragmented data management in ECC, ACDOCA integrates data from different modules and processes, providing a more comprehensive overview of financial obligations and their impact on the organization. 
  3. Extended analysis functions:
    With the ACDOCA data, organizations can perform complex analyses, such as plan/actual comparisons and trend analysis, which were previously difficult to carry out. This enables targeted management of the financial strategy and early identification of potential risks.     
  4. Flexibility and adaptability:
    ACDOCA's modern data structure supports easy adaptation to increasing requirements and the integration of new technologies such as AI-supported analyses and forecasts.     

This transition from COOI to ACDOCA clearly illustrates how SAP S/4HANA has advanced commitment management and supports companies in not only recording financial commitments, but also actively managing and strategically utilizing them. 

 GRAPHIC 2: Comparison of the commitment functionality in SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA 

 

Advantages of real-time data processing in SAP S/4HANA: 

  1. Application example - supply chain management:
    A company uses SAP S/4HANA to monitor its stock levels in real time. By recording orders and deliveries immediately, it can react more quickly to changes in demand and avoid bottlenecks. This leads to more efficient warehousing and reduced storage costs.
  2. Case study - Financial planning:
    A company in the energy sector implements SAP S/4HANA to gain real-time insight into its financial obligations. By immediately recording investment requests and provisions, the company can plan its liquidity more accurately and identify financial risks at an early stage. This leads to improved strategic decision-making and optimized budget management.     
  3.  

A new level of integration and analysis 

Another milestone is the seamless integration. SAP S/4HANA not only links MM, FI and CO technically, but also creates a unified view of obligations. This means that not only individual items, but also comprehensive budget evaluations or plan-versus-actual comparisons are possible at the touch of a button. 

At the same time, modern analytics functions offer new insights. Companies can recognize trends, identify anomalies at an early stage and make decisions based on reliable figures. 

Explanation of the Fiori interface and its advantages: 

The SAP Fiori interface offers a modern, intuitive and responsive design that greatly simplifies access to SAP applications. Users benefit from a role-based user experience that takes their specific tasks and needs into account. This enables a personalized and efficient way of working, as users can quickly access the information and functions relevant to their role without having to navigate through complex menus and transactions. The Fiori interface is particularly beneficial for users without in-depth technical system knowledge, as it facilitates the use of SAP applications and increases productivity through clear visualizations and simple interactions.  

GRAPHIC 3: SAP Fiori dashboard with current commitment values 

 

Exposure in the project business: actively managing cash flow 

Commitments have a particularly strategic impact in the project environment. SAP S/4HANA makes it possible to update payment obligations assigned to WBS elements, networks and orders, automatically and with precise value types. This creates the basis for project-related liquidity planning based on actual obligations. 

Down payments, allocations and project-related target/actual comparisons can also be clearly mapped. The ability to adjust financial items as required also increases flexibility. 

GRAPHIC 4: Project-oriented commitment process from the WBS element to the commitment 

Concrete implementation and specific functions of SAP S/4HANA 

User-friendliness thanks to the Fiori interface  

A key difference in the implementation of commitment management between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in the use of the modern Fiori interface, which enables more intuitive and user-friendly interaction. This interface supports a role-based and personalized user experience, allowing users to work efficiently without in-depth system knowledge. 

Use of intelligent functions for commitment management  

In addition, SAP S/4HANA offers specific functions such as AI-supported forecasting models that help to better manage future obligations and identify risks at an early stage. These models use historical data and probabilities to provide automated decision-making tools that significantly simplify commitment management. 

Technical implementation with CDS views and virtual data model 

In order to make optimum use of the functions and forecasting models mentioned, a robust database is required. The available CDS views in particular play a central role in analyzing the commitments. The content provides a manageable selection of CDS views that can be used to analyze the obligations. In the project context, it is advisable to check the associated virtual data model (VDM) and the definition of the key figures to see whether they reflect the requirements of the specialist area. This may result in expansion requirements that need to be mapped in the customer's own CDS views. In particular, when combining data from the two tables COOI and ACDOCA, it must be checked how these are merged. 

What's next? A look at the roadmap 

The development of SAP S/4HANA is far from complete. The upcoming releases promise, among other things, AI-supported forecasting models for commitment management. Automated decision-making aids based on historical data and probabilities will further reduce the burden on day-to-day business. 

A lot is also happening in terms of user-friendliness. The continuous improvement of the Fiori apps ensures that both controllers and project managers can work efficiently with commitments without in-depth system knowledge. 

Conclusion: Managing commitments, not just recording them 

Commitments not only show what a company has already incurred. They are a mirror of future expenditure and therefore an early warning system for the company's finances. SAP S/4HANA takes this tool to a new level by combining real-time data, integrated processes and dynamic analysis functions with modern implementation approaches and specific functions. With the Fiori interface and AI-supported forecasting models, commitments is transformed from a mere booking value into a strategic management tool. Companies that rely on these new possibilities can monitor commitments more specifically, manage budgets more precisely and identify financial risks earlier. The key to this lies in the intelligent use of existing data and a system that makes this data available in real time and in a user-friendly way. 

But that's just our view. How does your company perceive these changes? What experiences have you had with the implementation and use of SAP S/4HANA in commitment management? We look forward to hearing your perspectives and discussing new solutions together.

entry.title: SAP Ariba 2508 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Highlights of Enhancements across Procurement

Joule, Your AI Copilot

As you may know, Joule is the SAP AI copilot - a virtual assistant that uses a conversational interface to help users of SAP business applications complete tasks more efficiently.

The conversational interface is brought to life with the help of these 4 interaction patterns:

  • With informational interactions we are providing our users knowledge-based results. All SAP applications in which Joule is available make their knowledge-base available via Joule, e.g. SAP Help Documentation. This is managed by SAP and offered to every Joule user out of the box.
    We're also bringing in Document Grounding with which we enable our customers to upload their customer-owned content, e.g. HR-policies, travel-policies, FAQs, and others, so that their users can ask questions based on these documents.
  • Navigational Pattern - Easily navigate SAP applications by simply asking via natural language. Joule offers you a navigational link which opens the respective application and UI in a new browser tab. In the destination, a user can open Joule again and continue where they have left with the same conversation history.
  • Transactional interactions provide our users with a direct entry point to the backend system. Triggering and influencing business processes with the power of natural language and AI. E.g. purchase orders which need to be reviewed and approved, job positions which are created or any other CRUD-interaction (create, read, update, delete) within SAP cloud applications.
  • And a 4th, Analytical pattern to enable analytical interactions based on JustAsk and SAP Analytics Cloud, enabling customers to leverage Joule for analytical queries. This is currently not implemented in Ariba.

With the Q3 2025 release, Joule is being made available in the SAP Ariba applications of Guided Buying, Guided Sourcing and Supplier Management.

Please note that AI copilot Joule in the aforementioned products will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it will be made generally available to customers.

For a complete list of Transactional and Navigational Joule skills which are available per application area, view our new blog: Joule 2508 Release Key Innovations

 

SAP Ariba Category Management Highlights

Ability to Set an Initiative as Obsolete in SAP Ariba Category Management (ARBCATA-463)

Keeping your workspace organized is essential for focus and efficiency. With this feature you can now manually mark outdated initiatives as obsolete, easily closing those that are no longer relevant. This means your team will see only initiatives that matter, reducing clutter and helping everyone prioritize more effectively.

Additionally, the Initiatives Overview page now allows you to filter by multiple phases—including the Obsolete phase—so you can quickly get the view you need and keep data clean and actionable.

 

Standardized and Detailed Category Risk Assessment (ARBCATA-489)

Risk management is fundamental to strong category strategies. With this feature , the risk assessment tool has been enhanced so administrators can define standardized risk types for evaluation across all purchasing categories.

The new Risk Types page on the Strategy and Plan tab

Category managers can now identify, score, and qualify each risk in detail, with information like cause, impact, and mitigation strategies.

The New Risk page that appears when you click Create on the Risk Assessment page now includes 3 sections: Assessment, Details, and Mitigation. These scores contribute to an overall risk score at the strategy and plan level, which reflects the combined risk across category, timeframe, business unit, and region. This gives category managers a structured, repeatable approach to assessing category supporting informed decision-making at every level.

The Risk Assessment page now displays a Risk Assessment Matrix and Risks table.

 

Ability to Select Tool Documents for AI-generated Category Strategy Recommendations (CATMAN-16)

Now that it’s possible (with the above feature) to create multiple Cost Structure and Market Dynamics documents, this new AI-driven strategy recommendations allows you to choose which Cost Structure and Market Dynamics documents to include, ensuring the insights you receive are tailored to your specific business needs. This accelerates the development of effective strategies, minimizing revisions and aligning recommendations with your goals.

You can now choose specific Cost Structure and Market Dynamics documents when generating recommendations for category strategy details, in cases where multiple tool documents are linked to a strategy and plan document

For further details on these innovations and more, view our new blog:  Category Management 2508 Release Key Innovations

 

Highlights from Source-to-Contract

SAP Ariba Contracts Integration with WalkMe (SCONTR-1444)

This feature facilitates the integration between SAP Ariba Contracts and the WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform. Through this integration, buyers receive on-demand guidance from WalkMe for several commonly used workflows within SAP Ariba Contracts.

This enables organizations to accelerate user adoption of technology, boost productivity, and maximize the value of enterprise software investments.

Smart walk-throughs powered by WalkMe are available for the following workflows within SAP Ariba Contracts:
  • Creating a contract workspace
  • Importing line items into a contract workspace using the Simplified Excel Import functionality
  • Creating contract workspace templates

 

Managing Baseline and Supplier Contracts for Pre-Award Negotiation in Icertis Contract Intelligence for SAP Ariba Solutions (SCONTR-1499)

If your organization uses Icertis Contract Intelligence (ICI) alongside SAP Ariba, you can now manage both baseline and supplier contracts directly in Icertis during pre-award negotiations.

We've also improved the APIs so that developers can easily copy data from one contract workspace to another.

 

Display Remaining Time for Line Items in Bid Console for Guided Sourcing Auctions and Competitive RFPs (SOURCE-2544)

This feature enables buyers to view the remaining time for line items and lots within the Bid Console page and is applicable to guided sourcing events such as English forward auctions, English reverse auctions, and competitive RFPs.

Timing matters! The bid console now clearly shows how much time is left per line item (or lot) during auctions and RFPs.

 

The changes are applicable for competitive RFP, Auction, Reverse auction bid console screens. For Japanese, dutch auctions the new column Time remaining will not show and the watch screen timer values will not change.

 

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: Source-to-Contract 2508 Release Key Innovations

 

Highlights from Procure-to-Order

AI Copilot Joule in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1163) - GA September 19th 

AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying features a conversational interface designed to help users complete tasks efficiently. It leverages generative and other AI technologies to understand natural language requests, identify user intent, perform actions, and provide valuable insights.

With Joule, you can easily access information such as:

  • Requisition approval status
  • Requisition details
  • Recent purchases

You can find the Joule panel by clicking on the icon at the top of your screen. This release is just the beginning of our journey to harness AI across buying processes, driving significant efficiency gains and more for our entire user base.

Please note that AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it will be made generally available to customers

For more detailed information please see this blog: Joule in SAP Ariba Applications

 

Enhancements to WalkMe in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1266) 

We were excited to announce the first iteration of WalkMe in Guided Buying in the last release (2505), now to build on this momentum with an important user experience enhancement.

The WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform is now enabled for all Guided Buying customers and the WalkMe panel can now display content from SAP Companion also through some subtle UI changes.

If both WalkMe and SAP Companion are enabled, the walk me panel now displays a separate tab for each respectively:

 

Previously, WalkMe was disabled by default, and SAP Companion content displayed in a different panel.

This innovation offers more flexibility, allowing you to use the right resources and support at the right time in the most suitable way. It will help guide you seamlessly through your desired procurement processes and drive better outcomes.

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: Procure-to-Order 2508 Release Key Innovations

 

Highlights from Central Invoice Management

Enriched Filtering Capabilities for the Invoice List (CIM-2270) 

We know that dealing with large volumes of invoices can be challenging, especially when you need to find that one specific invoice or group relevant data for reporting and analysis. With our latest release, we’re streamlining this process even further.

Within the invoice list you can use the Adapt Filters button to add several new filters to the filter bar. For additional information on how to adapt filters in the invoice list, see Adapting Filters and Creating Variants. The following filters are now available:

  • Company Code Country/Region
  • Supplier Country/Region
  • Purchase Order

The new filters allow you to search the invoice list more precisely and accurately as seen in the image below:

 

Posting Date Automatically Updated During Automatic Processing (CIM-2920)

For organizations that use automatic processing for invoices in SAP Ariba, you likely set a default posting date—often the current date—when invoices are automatically submitted. With our new enhancement, if you have defined the default posting date as the current date, the system now dynamically updates the posting date to the exact current date right before the invoice is submitted.

We understand that sometimes, there may be a delay between when automatic processing starts and when an invoice is actually submitted. In the past, this gap meant an invoice could end up with a posting date that was out of alignment with the real submission time, potentially causing confusion or even issues with financial reporting or compliance.

With the new enhancement, the posting date will always reflect the true date of submission—even if the process experiences minor delays. This change can have a major impact for finance and accounting teams.

 

Submission of Invoices Enriched by Data Attribute Recommendation (CIM-2965)

With this feature, changes have been made to the automatic submission process for invoices enriched by data attribute recommendation. Now, when the confidence threshold for fields enriched by data attribute recommendation is between 0.5 and 0.7, the automatic submission is stopped, and you can review the fields within the invoice on the invoice detail page. You can then manually submit the invoice or adjust the invoice before submitting.

Data attribute recommendation can automatically enrich and complete the following fields in draft invoices:

  • G/L Account
  • Cost Center
  • WBS Element

Data attribute recommendation is a machine learning service that is trained with a set of invoices that you select. Once data attribute recommendation is trained and activated, SAP Ariba CIM can automatically complete missing fields in draft invoices using the data learned during the training.

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: Central Invoice Management 2508 Release Key Innovations

 

Highlights from Supplier Management & Risk

Supplier Management Integration with WalkMe (SLP-2265)
This feature integrates SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance and SAP Ariba Supplier Information and Performance Management (new architecture) with WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform. Users can take advantage of easy-to-understand guidance powered by WalkMe.

Supplier Management WalkMe integration includes several standard smart walk-throughs from SAP Ariba for common workflows. Customers can also choose to develop their own content by first purchasing WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba solutions. For more information about WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba solutions, see https://walkme.com

If you have an SAP Companion help system enabled, its help content remains available.

View implementation details and more here.

 

AI Copilot Joule in Supplier Management (SLP-2258)
Joule, SAP's generative AI copilot, is now available in supplier management. Joule uses a conversational interface to help users complete tasks efficiently. It leverages generative and other AI technologies to understand natural language requests, identify intent, perform actions, and provide insights. Using generative AI, it can execute tasks, deliver tailored responses, and summarize information effectively.

(IMPORTANT: AI Copilot Joule in SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance will be in early access until September 19th, 2025, at which time it will be made generally available to customers.)

View implementation details and more here.

For the list of tasks that you can perform using Joule, refer to the topic Joule Capabilities in Supplier Management.

 

Option to Join the SAP User Research Panel (SRISK-1771)
This feature provides you an option to join the SAP User Research Panel, where you can share your thoughts and ideas to enhance SAP Ariba Supplier Risk and other SAP products you currently use.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Risk Exposure Summary Report Displays Overall Residual and Inherent Risk Levels (SRISK-1763)

This feature provides information about the inherent and residual risk levels of suppliers in the Risk Exposure Summary report. This crucial information aids in making informed decisions when engaging with suppliers.

In addition to the existing risk exposure information, the Risk Exposure Summary report now includes two additional columns to provide inherent and residual risk level information for the suppliers you monitor in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Changes to the User Interface - Currently, the Risk Exposure Summary report summarizes the overall risk exposure, and category-wise risk exposure such as legal and regulatory, environmental and social, and operational risk exposure. This enhancement introduces two additional columns to display overall inherent risk level and residual risk level information for the suppliers you monitor in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

View implementation details and more here.

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: Supplier Management & Risk 2508 Release Key Innovations 

 

These innovations aim to significantly enhance your procurement and sourcing capabilities, leading to improved efficiency, data-driven insights, and strengthened supplier relationships.

 

Stay connected with our community for more insights and updates:

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2508 release (August 12-14, 2025)
  • Resources
    • Feature related materials:
      • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
      • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
    • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
    • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
    • What’s New
    • SAP Products and Services YouTube channel - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWV533hWWvDk7zRbhOsWQkF5BGWokhHYH
    • "Spend Management and Business Network" playlist - https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3ZRUb1AKkpSPtGOGv41NrN_6_WwyiYrF&si=29zqqpUPaRoKUvU4
    • Make sure to check out our other blogs and subscribe to all of our authors to keep up-to-date with the latest and greatest innovations!

entry.title: SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management 2508 Release Highlights
entry.content:
The 2508 release is one more example of how SAP Ariba is continuously working to simplify processes and create real value for our customers.  We are happy to introduce the following new features into your day-to-day invoice management process.

1.  Enriched Filtering Capabilities for the Invoice List (CIM-2270)

We know that dealing with large volumes of invoices can be challenging, especially when you need to find that one specific invoice or group relevant data for reporting and analysis. With our latest release, we’re streamlining this process even further.

Within the invoice list you can use the Adapt Filters button to add several new filters to the filter bar. For additional information on how to adapt filters in the invoice list, see Adapting Filters and Creating Variants. The following filters are now available:

  • Company Code Country/Region
  • Supplier Country/Region
  • Purchase Order

The new filters allow you to search the invoice list more precisely and accurately as seen in the image below:

2.  Posting Date Automatically Updated During Automatic Processing (CIM-2920)

For organizations that use automatic processing for invoices in SAP Ariba, you likely set a default posting date—often the current date—when invoices are automatically submitted. With our new enhancement, if you have defined the default posting date as the current date, the system now dynamically updates the posting date to the exact current date right before the invoice is submitted.

We understand that sometimes, there may be a delay between when automatic processing starts and when an invoice is actually submitted. In the past, this gap meant an invoice could end up with a posting date that was out of alignment with the real submission time, potentially causing confusion or even issues with financial reporting or compliance.

With the new enhancement, the posting date will always reflect the true date of submission—even if the process experiences minor delays. This change can have a major impact for finance and accounting teams.

3.  Submission of Invoices Enriched by Data Attribute Recommendation (CIM-2965)

With this feature, changes have been made to the automatic submission process for invoices enriched by data attribute recommendation. Now, when the confidence threshold for fields enriched by data attribute recommendation is between 0.5 and 0.7, the automatic submission is stopped, and you can review the fields within the invoice on the invoice detail page. You can then manually submit the invoice or adjust the invoice before submitting.

Data attribute recommendation can automatically enrich and complete the following fields in draft invoices:

  • G/L Account
  • Cost Center
  • WBS Element

Data attribute recommendation is a machine learning service that is trained with a set of invoices that you select. Once data attribute recommendation is trained and activated, SAP Ariba CIM can automatically complete missing fields in draft invoices using the data learned during the training.

4.  Automated Allocation of Assignment Groups to Supplier Invoices (CIM-2852)

With the new Configure Assignment Group Rules app, you can now create customized workflows that automatically allocate assignment groups to supplier invoices, whether they’re in Draft status or at the Draft and Completed status with Manual Adjustment Required as a process step. This feature streamlines the process, ensuring no invoice is left unassigned and reducing manual intervention.

In this app, you can create one-step or multi-step workflows. If the configured step conditions are met, the assignment group defined during the process is allocated to the supplier invoices. While this is in progress, the invoice remains in the Assignment Group Determination process step. After some time, it automatically moves to the next process step, even if the assignment group isn't allocated. To initiate the automatic allocation process again, you can select Assign by System under the Assign drop-down on the invoice list page or invoice detail page in the Manage Supplier Invoice Centrally app.

The screenshot below shows the buttons for creating and deploying variants:

5.  Verification of Tax at Line-Item Level (ITAP-31)

Tax regulations are complex and ever-changing. This new feature helps you align more closely with regulatory requirements by making sure each invoice line matches the correct tax calculation. Accurate tax validation reinforced at the line-item level makes audits simpler and lowers potential risk.

Users can make tax checks easily while editing invoices—catching and fixing issues before finalization. This smooths out the approval process, minimizes back-and-forth, and lets your finance team focus on strategic tasks instead of manual corrections.

In the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app, the Received Invoice Items section within the Invoice Items tab includes Tax Code, Tax Rate, and Tax Amount fields for each item. These fields are read-only. If there's a mismatch between the tax code and the expected tax code, or between the tax amount and the expected tax amount, a warning icon appears next to the corresponding field. In this situation, users need to manually adjust the entries for the respective line item to correct the difference.

With this feature, companies processing a high volume of invoices or operating in regions with complex tax codes will see measurable improvements in accuracy and compliance. Whether you’re managing local or global invoicing, this enhancement simplifies processes and mitigates risks.      

The screenshot below displays the new fields for the line item:

6.  Support for Material Information in the Purchasing Document Item (CIM-2990)

Efficient and accurate invoice management is a foundation of strong supplier relationships and healthy cash flow. Many businesses—especially those dealing with complex sourcing—face challenges when invoices cover multiple products or services. Matching these invoice items to the right purchasing document items can be time-consuming and error-prone, especially when crucial material details aren’t immediately available.

With this release, material information is now accessible for purchasing document items linked to invoice items, facilitating manual matching of complex invoices. It ensures accuracy and efficiency when handling complicated matching scenarios.

The screenshots below display the field where the material information is available:

7.  Enhancement to Additional Information About the Invoicing Party on the Invoice Detail Page (CIM-3124)

You can now display additional information about the invoicing party on the invoice detail page, which enables you to compare that information to the supplier data in the invoice. This way, you can ensure that the correct supplier has been selected.

In the app Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally, on the invoice details page, you can now display the contact and tax details of the selected invoicing party by clicking on the name of the supplier. The pop-up includes information such as the address, phone number, and tax details.

By providing richer, well-structured information at the right moment, this enhancement supports informed decision-making, faster processing of invoices, and more confident collaboration between buyers and suppliers. That translates into smoother operations—and measurable value for your business.

The 2508 release consists of enhancements based on the feedback we have received from our customers. With these enhancements, we believe your invoice activities will be simpler, faster and easier than ever.

Stay tuned for our additional upcoming blog posts and follow me to stay informed on upcoming feature releases across SAP Ariba. Once, these items are officially released on August 14th, the feature reference IDs, for example, CIM-2852, can help you to find more detailed information on http://help.sap.com.

Thank you for being a part of the SAP Ariba community and we look forward to continuing our journey of innovation together!

entry.title: Event-driven Architecture: Creating Fullstate Events in SAP S/4HANA for SAP EMIS
entry.content:
Intro 

Event-driven architecture (EDA) is a software architecture paradigm in which system components interact through the production, detection, and consumption of events. Instead of relying on a synchronous request/response model, EDA uses asynchronous communication, enabling components to react to state changes or occurrences in real time. This approach increas flexibility, scalability, and responsiveness, particularly in complex, distributed systems. In the context of SAP S/4HANA this paradigm shift is reflected in concept of so called “business events”.

An overview of released business events, for example for the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud, can be found in the SAP Business Accelorator Hub. 

Example: If you want to be notified about the creation or modification of business partner master data, you can use the SAP business event for business partners. 

Many of SAP standard business events are notification events. Notification events inform subscribers about the occurrence of an event, triggering actions or workflows without providing detailed context. They typically contain minimal informations, like an event ID or type, sufficient for consumers to decide whether further data retrieval is necessary. In case of our business partner example, only includes the BusinessPartner ID. Additionally SAP standard events can’t be filtered in SAP S/4HANA out of the box, meaning subscribers receive notifications for all creation or change events of every business partner even if only a dedicated type or group is relevant for them. 

Depending on the specific use case, it is advisable to evaluate whether notification events or full state events are more suitable. A comparison can be found below.

 

Criterion 

Notification Event 

Full State Event 

Definition 

Announces that something happened with minor context information

Announces that something happened  and includes the entire current state of an business object 

Content 

Minimal info (e.g., event type, object ID) 

Full object payload of the affected entity (e.g., full business partner  updated)

Typical Example 

BusinessPartner.Created.v1 (only partner ID)

BusinessPartner.Updated.v1 (full object payload)

Use Case 

For triggering workflows, alerts, initiates follow-up API calls or simple notifications  

For replication, synchronization, or direct downstream processing  

Data Dependency 

Requires consumers to fetch additional data from the producer

Self-contained — no need for follow-up API calls

Coupling 

Tightly coupled – consumers depend on producer APIs 

Loosely coupled – events are self-contained, no need for follow-up API calls 

Failure Tolerance 

Lower – if producer is down, data retrieval may fail

Higher – consumers can act without producer availability

Payload Size 

Small 

Larger 

Producer Complexity 

Low – only basic metadata required

Higher – must serialize and include full object state

Example Payload 

{ "event": "BusinessPartnerCreated", "partnerId": "BP12345" } 

{ "event": "BusinessPartnerUpdated", "partner": { ...full partner data... } } 

Check: Presenting Event Sources

The Use Case

The use case aims to enable the automatic validation of the country-specific VAT number for business partners with the country code 'CH'. Whenever a business partner VAT number is provided, it should automatically checked against the VAT IDs service published by the authorities. Each country maintains its own tax administration, e.g. Switzerland offers a public SOAP API for validating the Swiss VAT ID. This automated VAT number check ensures the complete and correct management of the business partner master data. In this specific case, correct use of the VAT number is also important for tax audits conducted by the tax authorities. 

Expected features/functionalities 

If a business partner is created or changed and has the country value 'CH' in any of its addresses, the VAT ID with the BPTaxNumberType = 'CH1' should be validated using the public SOAP API. If the VAT validation was successful, no further action is required. However if no VAT is maintained or the validation fails, both an email and a message to a webhook should be generated. 

Environment

The event is produced in the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. The requirement is implemented using the SAP Integration Suite and its components: SAP Event Mesh Integration Suite (EMIS) and Cloud Integration. A mail adapter and a webhook are used as consumers of the event. Alternatively, instead of SAP EMIS you can also use the SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM).

Simplified presentation of the use case with a full state event in a high level architecture. 

Set-Up-Connectivity: 

To set up connectivity for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP EMIS (or SAP AEM) you can refer to the following blog posts: 

  • SAP S/4HANA direct connectivity with Event Mesh in Integration Suite 
  • RAP Business Events with SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh and SAP S/4HANA On Premise 2023

Variante 1 – Using SAP Business Event for Business Partner Create/Change 

For the standard event, which is used first, a simple structure (notification event) is applied: the message contains only the ID field and the data in JSON format. A connection to EMIS/AEM is used, which requires an additional API call to retrieve the full data before further processing can take place. This iFlow becomes more complex due to the extra API Call. 

With the HTTPS sender adapter only JSON-formatted body is sent: 

{ 
"BusinessPartner":"1000540" 
}

Using the received BusinessPartnerNumber a query is made to SAP S/4HANA to retrieve additional data (such as name, address, country, BPTaxNumber, etc.). There are two options for the receiver adapter to obtain this data:

  • You can use an HTTP receiver adapter to receive the payload in JSON format or
  • an OData receiver adapter to receive the payload in XML format. 

In this interface there is no option to select the country directly. Therefore it was decided to use OData to retrieve the data in XML format and apply filtering during processing. 

With the OData receiver adapter the following settings are required:  

After receivíng the data, the next step is to route messages where the country is 'CH' (Switzerland). A message mapping is then performend to check if the BPTaxType = 'CH1'.  

We use a groovy script to set properties, so that we can later send emails containing the important information. The payload, from which the properties are extracted and which has now been converted from XML to JSON, looks like this:

{ 
  "A_BusinessPartner": { 
    "A_BusinessPartnerType": { 
      "BusinessPartner": "1000540", 
      "BusinessPartnerUUID": "6045bd9c-ea28-1fe0-8df5-064c8dfd4727", 
      "BusinessPartnerName": "Test RealCore Schweiz GmbH", 
      "to_BusinessPartnerAddress": { 
        "A_BusinessPartnerAddressType": [ 
          { 
            "BusinessPartner": "1000540", 
            "Country": "CH", 
            "FullName": "Test RealCore Schweiz GmbH", 
            "HouseNumber": "1", 
            "Language": "DE", 
            "StreetName": "Müligässli", 
            "PostalCode": "8598", 
            "AddressID": "29648" 
          }, 
          { 
            "BusinessPartner": "1000540", 
            "Country": "CH", 
            "FullName": "Test RealCore Schweiz GmbH", 
            "HouseNumber": "2", 
            "Language": "DE", 
            "StreetName": "Müligässli", 
            "PostalCode": "8598", 
            "AddressID": "29663" 
          }, 
        ] 
      }, 
      "to_BusinessPartnerTax": { 
        "A_BusinessPartnerTaxNumberType": { 
          "BusinessPartner": "1000540", 
          "BPTaxType": "CH1", 
          "BPTaxNumber": "CHE359123374", 
          "BPTaxLongNumber": "", 
          "AuthorizationGroup": "" 
        } 
      } 
    } 
  } 
}

To perform the correct action, you need to set and send a header in the API call. In our use case, the header should indicate  that the BPTaxNumber requires validation.  (Link to webservice and actions)

 

The HTTP receiver adapter is used to make the API call to validate the BPTaxNumber:

The API call returns a simple response: 

<s:Envelope xmlns:s="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"> 
  <s:Body xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> 
    <ValidateVatNumberResponse xmlns="http://www.uid.admin.ch/xmlns/uid-wse"> 
      <ValidateVatNumberResult>true</ValidateVatNumberResult> 
    </ValidateVatNumberResponse> 
  </s:Body> 
</s:Envelope>

All together the complete iFlow looks like this: 

In the teaser one benefit of full state events was highlighted: Simplified Architectures: Reduceing dependency on S/4HANA APIs, and lowering system coupling and load. However, with the interface described above, the simplified architecture is not archieved.

To address this, another solution is required: RAP event

A RAP event can be used to archieve simpler architecture, providing pre-selected and filtered events. Therefore, the solution chosen is to implement a custom RAP event.

You can find more information in the next blog of this serie: Event-driven Architecture: Creating Fullstate Events in SAP S/4HANA for SAP Event Mesh on Integration Suite (EMIS) - RAP Edition (coming soon…).

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - New (Measure Based) Model with Account Dimension - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

The new model in SAP Analytics Cloud combines the power of measures and account dimensions to deliver flexible and detailed planning. By supporting both numeric measures and structured financial accounts, it enables accurate reporting, advanced calculations, and seamless analysis. This blog explores how this hybrid approach enhances modeling and decision-making in SAC.

Step 1: - From the Navigation panel, select Modeler, choose Start with empty model, and then click Create, as illustrated in the screenshot below.

After clicking Create, the following screenshot illustrates that Version and Date dimensions are added by default.

Step 2: - Add Measure

Note: Adding at least one measure is mandatory when creating a new Measure Based Model.

To add a measure, click the ‘+’ icon in the model structure workspace.

In the model panel, provide a Name and an optional Description for the measure.

Enter the required details — Data Type, Aggregation, Units & Conversion, and Formatting, if needed.

Similarly, I have added two additional measures.

Step 3: - Add Dimension

To add a dimension, click the ‘+’ icon in the model structure workspace.

 

Scenario 1 – Generic Type

In the Dimension creation panel, provide the Name (here, Product) of the dimension, select the Dimension Type (here, Generic), and click the Add button to create the dimension.

        

 

Scenario 2 – Organization Type

In the Dimension creation panel, provide the Name (here, Region) of the dimension, select the Dimension Type (here, Organization), and click the Add button to create the dimension.

Scenario 3 – Account Type

In the Dimension creation panel, provide the Name (here, Account) of the dimension, select the Dimension Type (here, Account), and click the Add button to create the dimension.

Scenario 4 – Add Existing Dimension Table

To add an existing dimension table, you need to select a public dimension table from the available options. However, in my current scenario, I am not using this option.

Step 4: - Configure the Dimension Table according to the available data, as shown below.

Prior to configuring the Dimension Table, refer to the table structure. The reference table is provided below.

RegionProductMonthAccountValueQuantity SoldReturnsVersionCategoryHierarchy
NorthPhone202501Cost10000050010public.ActualActualsRevenue
NorthPhone202501Cost6000050010public.ActualActualsRevenue
NorthPhone202501Profit4000050010public.ActualActualsRevenue
SouthLaptop202501Profit800003005public.ActualActualsRevenue
SouthLaptop202501Cost500003005public.ActualActualsRevenue
SouthLaptop202501Profit300003005public.ActualActualsRevenue

1] Account

Click on Edit Dimension Table for the Account, as highlighted.

Based on the table structure, the Account dimension is configured as shown below.

Note:

  1. When editing the Dimension Table for Account, where the Dimension Table Type is set to Account, the columns Member ID, Description, Hierarchy, Formula, Account Type, Aggregation Type, Exception Aggregation Type, Exception Aggregation Dimension, Required Dimensions, Scale, Decimal Places, Units & Currencies, Threshold and Hide are automatically included by default.
  2. For a Private Account Dimension, it is mandatory to have the Hierarchy column defined in the table structure, and this column must be mapped during data import.

 

2]Date

Click on Edit Dimension Table for the Date, as highlighted.

Set the Date settings according to the period specified in the reference table, as illustrated below.

3]Product

Click on Edit Dimension Table for the Product, as highlighted.

Based on the table structure, the Product dimension is configured as shown below.

Note: When editing the Dimension Table for Product, where the Dimension Table Type is set to Generic, the columns Member ID and Description are automatically included by default.

4]Region

Click on Edit Dimension Table for the Region, as highlighted.

 

Based on the table structure, the Region dimension is configured as shown below.

Note: When editing the Dimension Table for Region, where the Dimension Table Type is set to Organization, the columns Member ID, Description, Currency, and Person Responsible are automatically included by default.

Step 5: - Save the Model.

Once the Configuration is completed, one can save the model.

After completing the configuration, proceed to save the model.

Note: The model can be saved even after adding all the required dimensions and measures.

Click on the  Save icon to save the changes made to the model.

Enter the Name and an optional Description, then click the Save button.

Looking Ahead
We’ve successfully created a new model with an Account dimension. In the upcoming blogs, we’ll explore how to import data into this model and bring it to life with real insights.

Thank you for taking the time to read my blog—I hope you found it helpful! If you did, please like, share, and leave a comment.

Stay safe and stay curious!

SAP Analytics Cloud SAP Analytics Cloud, data modeling

entry.title: SAP Signavio Process Intelligence + Joule ( or other AI Agent) + Process Manager DMN ?
entry.content:
Dear Experts,
I have the following scenario in mind and would like your opinions on the possibility of implementing it.
A company has S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition 2024 with a transaction Z (clean core was not used) with numerous business rules. This transaction actually calls several tables (25 in total), where each table has business rules defined. These are regulatory rules from the country's energy agency.
These rules relate to master data of cost collectors as well as transactional data. (Ex.: a certain invoice or goods receipt was incorrectly posted with material X because it has rules in its master data that prevented it from being assigned to cost collector Y—also due to rules in its master data).
Assuming I have already mapped a material consumption process to these cost collectors in Signavio Process Manager, I can also assume I have created DMN (decision model and notation) rules that include the rules of transaction Z described above. Now, suppose I extract the data from S/4HANA with Signavio Process Intelligence and feed it into this process.

Could I create an agent (if necessary, of course) to check all my DMNs and compare them with the values in the extracted event log?

Or would I have to do it "manually"? That is, link each activity to a DMN (can I link more than one DMN to the same activity in Process Manager?) and create widgets to compare these values?

It would be very valuable if I could have some way to check (an agent perhaps?) all the rules and compare them with the activities mapped in the extracted process.

Any suggestions?

entry.title: Re: Cloud Integration - What You Need to Know About the Kafka Adapter
entry.content:
@jens_kordowski I have a question about batch processing.

I receive a bulk message and want to send each individual message to Kafka. Using an Iterating Splitter, the bulk message is split into its individual parts.

The settings for the Iterating Splitter are as follows:

Grouping: 1
Streaming: true

Here are my Kafka settings:

Max Request Size: 1080
Max Numer of Inflight Request: 5
Retry Backoff: 1000
Compression: ZSTD
Enable Batch: true
Batch Size: 1024
Linger: 200

In the trace monitor, I noticed that the request waits 200 ms for each message. This behavior is not what I expected - I would have assumed it waits 200 ms only after the last request.

entry.title: Re: Custom Fields & Logic App development tenant
entry.content:
When working with Custom Fields and Logic Apps in a development tenant, it’s important to ensure that your environment is properly configured to support customization and automation. Typically, a development tenant allows you to safely create and test custom fields, workflows, and logic without affecting your production data.

For Custom Fields:

Make sure your tenant permissions allow creating and modifying schema or metadata.

Plan your custom fields carefully to align with your business logic and data model.

Test the impact of custom fields on forms, views, and integrations.

For Logic Apps:

Use your development tenant to build and test workflows, connectors, and triggers.

Validate authentication and API connections within the tenant to avoid runtime errors.

Monitor runs and logs in the development environment to troubleshoot issues early.

If your development tenant has restrictions or sandbox limitations, check with your platform admin or documentation to understand what’s allowed. Using a dedicated dev tenant is a best practice to ensure smooth deployment to production once your customizations and logic are finalized.

entry.title: Building Stories That Other Developers Actually Want to Inherit
entry.content:
As SAC developers, we primarily focus on end-user requirements and experience, while also considering the broader impact of the content we build (network and source system performance).

But how often have you revisited an SAC story to enhance it, or inherited one created by someone else only to be confronted with a myriad of widgets using default names, no logical grouping, and layouts that require painful dragging and dropping to adjust?
In this blog, we’ll look at best practices based on experience that will make your life, and the lives of your fellow SAC developers far easier.

Naming Conventions
If you’ve read this far and get no further, the biggest single thing you can do to make developing SAC content easier is to use naming conventions.

  • Create a set of standard naming conventions for widgets
  • Give widgets meaningful names
  • Don’t get lazy and stop doing it

Below is an example of the prefixes I use, the main point being use something that works for you and your colleagues.
* Ensure it’s included in your organisation’s design guidelines

Widget Type

Standard Pre-Fix

Example

Bar Chart

chartB_

chartB_revenue_by_state

Line Chart

chartL_

chartL_margin_by_product

Numeric Point Chart

kpi_

kpi_actuals_vs_budget

Waterfall Chart

chartWF_

chartWF_spend

Table

tbl_

tbl_invoices_by_month

Panel

pnl_

pnl_title

Text Box

txt_

txt_title

Image

img_

img_logo

Shape

shape_

shape_header_divider

Button

btn_

btn_page2

Dropdown List

ddl_

ddl_product

List Box

lb_

lb_store

Radio Button Group

rbg_

rbg_managers

No one wants to see this in the outline view when editing a story!

When writing script it’s really not helpful hitting CTRL space and getting a meaningless list of charts……err which one was it again??

Far nicer to be presented with this.

Layouts
When building a story, I use panels wherever possible to group content, based on 100’s of story builds over the years I’ve yet to see a significant performance impact of using many panels within a SAC story.

Grouping content allows you to quickly navigate to it in design mode, makes it super easy to move blocks of content around if the layout needs changing.
It also makes scripting far simpler when you need to show/hide content (just hide the panel, not all the widgets it contains individually)

Example
This is typically how I structure a story layout, each distinct block of content is contained within a panel, you can also see in the outline view that the content is logically ordered top to bottom and left to right.

The same logical order (and naming convention) is carried on within each panel

At a glance you should be able to understand what is what and where it is, without even seeing the widgets in the main story window.

 

Script structure and annotation

This topic has been written about, probably shortly after the first ever line of code or script was created 😊
Yet it’s incredibly rare I open a SAC Story created by someone else and find fully documented script.
Even rarer is to find script that is not only annotated at a line level but also contains a summary level comment.
Summary level annotation provides great insight into the logic, how the block of code fits into the overall design & interaction with other code blocks.

As a quick example, here’s part of the code I wrote for a noughts and crosses game in SAC

 

Here’s part of the same script with annotation and a summary.
Someone else picking up work on this story would quickly be able to understand the logic and how the code interacts with other script in the story.

In this example I simply pasted the code into Chat GPT and asked it to annotate and summarise the script.
It did a fairly decent job, but you should always sanity check the output.

Other Thoughts

Panel Auto Scroll
I always turn this off, no one needs yet more scroll bars!
plus it makes it harder to arrange content within panels if there’s no hard stop on the widget layout position.

Flow Panels
Awful things 😊 they make setting up layouts really painful and shouldn’t be needed if you’re clear about what you’re building.

Dynamic Layout / Sizing
It’s always a challenge to build a story that looks good on varying screen sizes.
I typically build the story using auto widget widths and fixed px left and rights values, once I’m happy with the overall layout I change the Left/Right px unit to %
This allows widgets to auto size better when screen sizes vary.
You can go a step further and setup a number of CSS styles to change font sizes etc when the widget size changes.

Summary
Taking the time to apply consistent naming conventions, logical layouts, and well-structured, annotated scripting is about building SAC stories that are scalable, maintainable, and developer friendly.
Whether you're handing a project over to a colleague or revisiting it six months later, these habits dramatically reduce friction and improve development efficiency.

Good design isn’t just for end users, it starts with the developer.

entry.title: Re: how create validation for OSPP table -HANA DB
entry.content:
Ok I was wrong, it actually a TAB between CardCode and ItemCode, not a regular space. So this works fine

IF :object_type = N'7' AND (:transaction_type = N'U') THEN
	SELECT IFNULL(COUNT(*),0) INTO CNT1
	FROM OSPP T0
	WHERE ifnull(T0."U_LeadBy",'')= ''  
	and ifnull(T0."ItemCode",'') != '' 
	and (T0."CardCode" || char(9) || T0."ItemCode")=:list_of_cols_val_tab_del
	;
	if CNT1 > 0 THEN
		begin
               error := 1;
               error_message := N'pls updateU_LeadBy for ' || :list_of_cols_val_tab_del;
       end;
   end if;
end if;
CNT1 := 0;

entry.title: NEW IN THE SAP STORE: THE DHC SMART VALIDATION ACCELERATOR IS NOW AVAILABLE!
entry.content:
Life Sciences are going smart with automated validation for SAP cloud systems!

Digital transformation in regulated industries is advancing, as are the demands for efficient, auditable and scalable validation. This is precisely the area in which the DHC Smart Validation Accelerator from DHC Dr. Herterich & Consultants GmbH comes in. It is now officially available in the SAP® Store.

 

SO, WHAT IS THE DHC SMART VALIDATION ACCELERATOR?
It is a powerful extension for SAP Cloud ALM, specially developed for companies in the life sciences industry. This solution automates the validation of GxP-relevant SAP systems, including S/4HANA, SAP Digital Manufacturing and the Batch Release Hub.

The goal is to reduce manual effort, achieve faster GxP compliance and shorten project runtimes, all within the existing SAP ecosystem.

WHY DOES THIS MATTER?
“With its availability on the SAP Store, we are reaching a new milestone,” explains Dr Rudi Herterich, CEO of DHC. ‘Regulated companies need solutions that keep pace with increasingly complex requirements. The DHC Smart Validation Accelerator delivers exactly that, through intelligent automation, audit-proof documentation, and seamless SAP integration.'

TOP FEATURES AT A GLANCE:

  • Automated validation processes using guided workflows and templates
  • Audit-ready documentation with version history and full traceability
  • Flexible reporting functions to support audits and inspections
  • Lifecycle compliance: from planning and risk analysis to testing and release
  • Efficient change management, which is particularly valuable for frequent cloud updates.

TECHNOLOGICALLY FUTURE-PROOF.
The solution is based on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and uses the SAP Integration Suite, the SAP AI Launchpad and the SAP AI Core, among other things. Seamless integration with SAP Cloud ALM establishes the accelerator as a pivotal component in a contemporary validation strategy.

A WIN FOR REGULATED INDUSTRIES!

This solution is particularly beneficial for companies in the pharmaceutical, biotech and medical technology industries. This is because validation efforts are growing, both in terms of new technologies and due to ever-shorter release cycles and ever-increasing compliance expectations.

The DHC Smart Validation Accelerator enables companies to maintain control over their processes while ensuring maximum audit readiness.

IT IS AVAILABLE IN THE SAP STORE.

The SAP Store is a central marketplace offering over 2,300 SAP and partner solutions. All purchases also support SAP's sustainability initiatives, such as planting a tree for every order.

ABOUT DHC

Dr. Herterich & Consultants GmbH

DHC has been a leader in providing SAP-based solutions for regulated industries for nearly 30 years. The company combines in-depth regulatory knowledge with SAP technology expertise to deliver compliance that grows with your business. As an SAP partner and co-creator of the SAP Digital Validation Platform, DHC is driving the automation of validation processes.
